title: Torque - justify greater torque on bar

content.question: A bar of length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> and negligible mass is free to rotate about a pivot located a distance <math alttext="One third L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> from its right end, as shown in the figure. Two applied forces, <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="F sub 2 equals 2 F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, are exerted on the bar at the locations and in the directions shown. Which force results in a torque of greater magnitude about the pivot, and what reasoning supports this claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the lever arm is zero for <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

<math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the product <math alttext="F sub 1 end sub, L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mi>L</mi></math> is greater than <math alttext="F sub 2 end sub, one third L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>.

<math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is greater than <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

<math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, because <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is directed along the length of the rod.

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, because the lever arm is zero for <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.
